citations.narrative:
The facility's contingency plan has not been reviewed since January 2024. Failure to conduct annual contingency plan
reviews reduces the capability for disaster response and may negatively impact animal welfare in the event of
emergencies. The facility must ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed annually and that this review is documented.
Additionally, this documentation must be available to APHIS upon request.
Correct by 30 June 2025.

Multiple sections of the perimeter fence have fist-sized gaps at the base that do not meet the ground and are
approximately 4-6 inches in height. Wild animal droppings (likely rabbit) were accumulating on the ground at one gap.
Perimeter fences that fail to restrict entry of animals may cause harm to animals in the facility through injury or disease.
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence constructed so that it protects the animals within by
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it. An additional function of the perimeter
fence is to act as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.
Correct by 13 June 2025.

There are multiple worn surfaces in bird enclosures including a wooden vertical board in a Bald Eagle's ("Aurora")
enclosure that appears to be heavily chewed. There are also missing parts or heavily water damaged areas of wooden
boards where the walls meet the ground in a Turkey Vulture ("Quanah") enclosure and the enclosure for two California
Condors ("Marble" and "Millie"). Failure to maintain primary enclosures of birds in good repair may impede proper
cleaning and sanitization of interior surfaces with which the bird may come into contact. Primary enclosures must be
designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound and they must be kept in good repair.
Correct by 31 July 2025.

On the morning of 22 October 2024, an American Kestrel "Veto" was found stuck by his nails on the felt pad flooring
material of his primary enclosure and appeared fatigued. Injuries sustained required veterinary medical care. Failure to
provide flooring material that protects the birds' feet and legs from injury can lead to unnecessary pain and discomfort of
the animal. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they have floors that
protect the birds' feet and legs from injury.
Correct from this date forward of 06 June 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The facility's contingency plan has not been reviewed since January 2024. Failure to conduct annual contingency plan 
reviews reduces the capability for disaster response and may negatively impact animal welfare in the event of 
emergencies. The facility must ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed annually and that this review is documented. 
Additionally, this documentation must be available to APHIS upon request. 
 
Correct by 30 June 2025. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Multiple sections of the perimeter fence have fist-sized gaps at the base that do not meet the ground and are 
approximately 4-6 inches in height. Wild animal droppings (likely rabbit) were accumulating on the ground at one gap. 
Perimeter fences that fail to restrict entry of animals may cause harm to animals in the facility through injury or disease. 
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence constructed so that it protects the animals within by 
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it. An additional function of the perimeter 
fence is to act as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.  
 
Correct by 13 June 2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There are multiple worn surfaces in bird enclosures including a wooden vertical board in a Bald Eagle's ("Aurora") 
enclosure that appears to be heavily chewed. There are also missing parts or heavily water damaged areas of wooden 
boards where the walls meet the ground in a Turkey Vulture ("Quanah") enclosure and the enclosure for two California 
Condors ("Marble" and "Millie"). Failure to maintain primary enclosures of birds in good repair may impede proper 
cleaning and sanitization of interior surfaces with which the bird may come into contact. Primary enclosures must be 
designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound and they must be kept in good repair.

Correct by 31 July 2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(x) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
On the morning of 22 October 2024, an American Kestrel "Veto" was found stuck by his nails on the felt pad flooring 
material of his primary enclosure and appeared fatigued. Injuries sustained required veterinary medical care. Failure to 
provide flooring material that protects the birds' feet and legs from injury can lead to unnecessary pain and discomfort of 
the animal. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they have floors that 
protect the birds' feet and legs from injury. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 06 June 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
